clinical_study.brief_title: Optical Elastography of Systemic Sclerosis Skin
clinical_study.official_title: Optical Elastography of Systemic Sclerosis Skin

lead_sponsor.agency: The University of Texas Health Science Center, Houston

clinical_study.source: The University of Texas Health Science Center, Houston

brief_summary.textblock: The goal of this study is to develop a new way to assess skin thickness in patients with scleroderma (systemic sclerosis). The study will test how well a new imaging method called optical coherence elastography (OCE) compares to the current clinical method used to estimate skin thickness, the modified Rodnan Skin Score (mRSS).

secondary_outcome.measure: Skin thickness as assessed by Modified Rodnan Skin Score (mRSS)
Fibrosis score as assessed by forearm skin punch biopsy
secondary_outcome.description: A score based on histological findings of skin punch biopsy will be calculated. There some minor risk involved with skin biopsy procedure.

secondary_outcome.measure: Disability as assessed by the Scleroderma Health Assessment Questionnaire

arm_group.arm_group_label: Optical Elastography Assessment of Skin Thickness

intervention.description: To image skin thickness, Optical Coherence Elastography (OCE)-scanning of 6 body surface areas will be preformed using the Phase-Stabilized Swept Source Optical Coherence Elastography (PhS-SSOCE) system.
intervention.arm_group_label: Optical Elastography Assessment of Skin Thickness

intervention.description: Skin thickness will be visually assessed clinically in 6 body surface areas using the the modified Rodnan Skin Score (mRSS). The mRSS uses a 0-3 scale, where 0 = normal, 1= mild thickness, 2 = moderate thickness, and 3 = severe thickness

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria for scleroderma patients:
- meet the 2013 American College of Rheumatology and the European League Against Rheumatism (ACR/EULAR) criteria for systemic sclerosis with limited or diffuse cutaneous involvement
Exclusion Criteria:
- have another skin disease other than systemic sclerosis
